questions.text: The roots and leaves of the following plant given in the image below were burned and the smoke inhaled to treat asthma in India. The plant is also called as jimsonweed. Which amongst the following is the scientific name of the plant being described here?
questions.solution:
The above plant is Datura stramonium also called as jimsonweed.

The active ingredient present in Datura stramonium include atropine, scopolamine, and others, which help in relieving the symptoms associated with asthma (inhibition of M3 receptors on bronchi leading to decrease in bronchospasm and tracheobronchial secretions).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number. 127

questions.text: A 56 year old patient with hepatic cirrhosis came to medicine department with some abnormal looking pattern over skin as shown in the image below. Which of the following hormone is the most likely culprit for the production of such lesions?
questions.solution:
The image shows a spider nevus. Vascular spider nevi have been attributed to excessive levels of estrogen because estrogens cause blood vessels to enlarge and dilate.

It is commonly seen in patients with cirrhosis and in those taking estrogen-containing contraceptives. Serum estradiol and total testosterone levels are altered particularly in male patients with cirrhosis due to the ineffective hepatic metabolism of estrogen and spider nevi are common in male cirrhosis patients.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, page number 318

questions.text: A 45 year old female came to emergency department with swollen legs as shown in the image below with tenderness. The clinical presentation in the below image is likely caused by which of the following drug?
questions.solution:
Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator with estrogen agonist action on bone and liver. It is associated with 3-fold increased risk of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism and is contraindicated in adults with a history of venous thromboembolism.

Other Side effects

Hot flashes, leg cramps are generally mild; vaginal bleeding is occasional.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number. 338-339

questions.text: A 56 year old patient developed the following lesions after 10 days of treatment. Patient also complains of similar lesions over soles and they are sensitive to touch. The most likely agent to cause that adverse effect is?
questions.solution:
Hand foot syndrome or palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia consists of erythema, desquamation, pain and sensitivity to touch of the palms and soles.

Drugs commonly implicated are:

  • Capecitabine
  • 5-Fluorouracil
  • Cytarabine
  • Pemetrexed
  • Doxorubicin

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number. 923

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was taking multiple medicines for his chronic condition as suggested by his physician, presents with a round macule on his right leg as shown in image below for past 7 days. The patient also gives history similar episodes over the past 8 years which resolve spontaneously after 7-10 days. Which of the following is most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Ibuprofen is the offending agent. This is a case of fixed drug eruption. The lesion recurs in the same locations upon re-exposure to the offending drug. Antibacterial sulphonamides, antibiotics, NSAID's, analgesics, and hypnotics are the most frequent causes of FDE Diagnosis is based on history and lesion morphology.

Discontinuation of the offending drug is the first step in management.

Phenytoin and carbamazepine are causes of drug-induced Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) and drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symploms (DRESS syndrome). Captopril, which is an ACEI, can cause anaphylactic reaction with urticaria.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number. 214

questions.text: A 45 yr old female on prescription of an anti-hypertensive drug, gradually started to develop joint pain, muscle pain and fever. There was associated photosensitivity and skin changes as shown in figure. On investigation, ANA was positive. Which of the following drug would have caused this?
questions.solution:
Drug induced SLE:

(Mnemonic --- SHIP)

  1. Sulfonamides
  2. Hydralazine
  3. Isoniazid
  4. Procainamide

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number:613

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can result in the below condition?
questions.solution:
Bismuth subsalicylate

It is thought to act by decreasing PG synthesis in the intestinal mucosa, thereby reducing Cl¯ secretion. It has some prophylactic value in travellers' diarrhoea (probably due to weak antibacterial action as well)

Dark stools (sometimes mistaken for melena) and black staining of the tongue in association with bismuth compounds are caused by bismuth sulfide formed in a reaction between the drug and bacterial sulfides in the GI tract.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13th edition, page number. 931

choices.text: Galactosidase, Increased utilization of metabolic end product
Glucocerebrosidase, Decreased utilization of metabolic end product
Galactosidase, Formation of an abnormal metabolic end product

questions.text: A 27 years old man complains of recurrent bone pain and increasing abdominal girth. On physical examination, his physician reveals massive hepatosplenomegaly and suggested bone marrow biopsy which showed following picture. Radiologic findings are in favor of radiolucent bone defects. This patient most likely carries mutation in the gene that encodes which of the following types of hydrolytic enzymes and the pathogenesis of this?
questions.solution:
Autosomal recessive disorders resulting from mutations in the gene encoding

GLUCOCEREBROSIDASE.

deficiency: B-glucocerebrosidase

Accumulation of glucocerebroside, primarily in the lysosomes of macrophages. (Choice D)

Most Common Lysosomal storage disease

  • TRIAD
    1. Hepatomegaly
    2. Gaucher Cell in BM
    3. Increased serum phosphatase
  • The hallmark of this disorder is the presence of GAUCHER CELLS, which are lipid- laden macrophages that are characteristically present in the red pulp of the spleen, liver sinusoids, lymph nodes, lungs, and bone marrow.
  • These cells are derived from the resident macrophages in the respective organs (e.g., Kupffer cells in the liver and alveolar macrophages in the lung).
  • Galactosidase gene mutations (choice A) are found in patients with Fabry disease.
  • Glucosylceramide is a common core structure for membrane glycosphingolipids. The glucosylceramide that accumulates in Gaucher cells in the spleen, liver, bone marrow, and lymph nodes derives principally from the catabolism of senescent leukocytes. The membranes of these cells are rich in the cerebrosides, and when their degradation is blocked by the deficiency of glucocerebrosidase, the intermediate metabolite, glucosylceramide, accumulates.
  • The other biochemical pathways listed do not cause sphingolipid accumulation in patients with lysosomal storage diseases.
  • Mutation of the glucocerebrosidase gene is the most Common known genetic risk factor for development of PARKINSON DISEASE. Patients with Gaucher disease have a 20-fold higher risk of developing Parkinson disease (compared with controls), and 5% to 10% of patients with Parkinson disease have mutations in the gene encoding glucocerebrosidase.

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 5, pg number:158, 159.

questions.text: A 7 year-old boy with a history of diabetes complains of recent changes in his bodily appearance. Laboratory studies reveal elevated serum corticosteroids and low serum corticotropin. Administration of dexamethasone does not lower serum levels of corticosteroids. A photograph of the patient is shown in the image. This patient most likely has a tumor that originates in which of the following anatomic locations?
questions.solution:
Cushing syndrome presents with an accumulation of subcutaneous fat on the posterior neck ('buffalo hump'), striae, and diabetes mellitus.

In this case, the disorder was caused by an adrenal tumor, which could have been either a cortical adenoma or carcinoma.

The typical adenoma is an encapsulated, firm, yellow, slightly lobulated mass, measuring about 4 cm in diameter, which secretes glucocorticoid hormones.

Tumors of the zona glomerulosa (choice B) secrete aldosterone (min- eralocorticoid), and those of the adrenal medulla (choice C) are pheochromocytomas that secrete epinephrine.

Lack of dexamethasone suppression rules out pituitary adenoma (choice D).

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 24, pg number: 1115- 1117.

questions.text: A middle aged man who is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis, complains of swelling of his eyelids and ankle. He has bilateral pleural effusion, without evidence of pulmonary infiltration which is revealed on chest X-ray. Urinalysis reveals heavy proteinuria and renal biopsy PAS negative glomerular deposits as shown in the microphotograph. This acellular material obstructing the glomerular capillaries is most likely derived from which of the following serum proteins?
questions.solution:
REACTIVE SYSTEMIC AMYLOIDOSIS (Secondary amyloidosis)

  • The amyloid deposits are composed of AA protein.
  • AA amyloid is common to a host of seemingly unrelated, persistent, inflammatory, neoplastic, and hereditary disorders that lead to so-called secondary amyloidosis.
  • Reactive systemic amyloidosis complicates rheumatoid arthritis, other connective tissue disorders such as ankylosing spondylitis, and inflammatory bowel disease, both Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis.
  • Among these, the most frequently associated condition is rheumatoid arthritis. Amyloidosis is reported to occur in approximately 3% of patients with rheumatoid arthritis and is clinically significant in one-half of those affected.
  • There is a spectrum of AA peptides of differing size in the deposits, all of which have the same amino- terminal sequence. This includes the intact precursor of AA, serum amyloid A (SAA).
  • SAA is an acute-phase reactant protein that increases up to 1,000-fold during inflammatory processes.
  • Denaturing of SAA releases a subunit termed apoSAA, which renders it amyloidogenic.
  • In contrast to AL protein derived from immunoglobulin light chain (choice C), the amino acid sequence of AA proteins is identical in all patients, regardless of the underlying disorder.
  • Progressive glomerular obliteration may ultimately lead to renal failure.

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 6, page number:. 262.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman who has a family history of breast cancer presents with a 6-month history of increasing abdominal girth. She has no children and has never been pregnant. Bimanual pelvic examination reveals a 9x6 cm right adnexal mass. Percussion of the abdomen indicates ascites and aspiration cytology of the ascites fluid is positive for malignancy. She undergoes surgery to have the mass removed. Histologic examination of the surgical specimen is shown in the following two images. This neoplasm most likely originated from which of the following ovarian cells/tissues?
questions.solution:
SURFACE EPITHELIUM.

  • The tumor depicted is a PAPILLARY SEROUS CYSTADENOCARCINOMA. (Ovarian tumor – Surface epithelial tumors)
  • The most frequently encountered ovarian tumors (e.g., benign and malignant serous and mucinous neoplasms) arise from the surface epithelium and are termed common epithelial tumors.
  • Epidemiologic studies suggest that common epithelial neoplasms are related to repeated disruption and repair of the epithelial surface during normal cyclic ovulation.
  • Thus, these tumors most commonly afflict women who are nulliparous and, conversely, occur least often in women in whom ovulation has been suppressed (e.g., by pregnancy or oral contraceptives).
  • Germ cells (choice A) give rise to benign teratomas and a variety of malignant tumors.
  • The other cells give rise to sex cord/stromal tumors. (Choice B, C)
  • Psammoma body formation is seen in the first microphotograph.
  • The second microphotograph reveals papillary structure having cuboidal to columnar cells are seen lining the wall of the cysts and the papillae.
  • PSAMMOMA BODIES (concentric lamellated, calcified structures associated with papillary histomorphology) are seen in :-

(Mnemonic- PM PPPM SPM)

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma
  • Meningioma
  • Papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma of ovary
  • Papillary renal carcinoma
  • Papillary serous Endometrial carcinoma
  • Mesothelioma- peritoneal and pleural
  • Somatostatinoma
  • Prolactinoma of the pituitary
  • Micropapillary lung adenocarcinoma

Reference: Rosai And Ackerman's Surgical Pathology, 11th Edition, Chapter 35, page number:1377-1379.

questions.text: A 46 years old woman presents with right breast mass found a week ago. A breast biopsy reveals malignant cells and mastectomy is performed. Immunohistochemical staining is performed for HER2/neu as per following image. Which of the following genetic mechanisms best accounts for the intensity of staining in the specimen?
questions.solution:
• Overexpression of HER2/neu is identified in 10% to 35% of primary breast tumors and is mostly attributable to GENE AMPLIFICATION.
  • Amplification or overexpression of HER2/neu has also been described in cancers of the lung, ovary, and stomach.
  • Patients whose tumors demonstrate HER2 gene amplification benefit from therapy with a monoclonal antibody (Herceptin) that selectively binds to the extracellular domain of the protein.
  • Although the other genetic processes occur in some cancers, they are unrelated to HER2/neu expression.
  • HER2 overexpression and amplification can be measured by immunohistochemistry or fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) (or its chromogenic equivalent), respectively, and a good correlation exists between these methods.

Reference: Rosai And Ackerman's Surgical Pathology, 11th Edition, Chapter 36, page number:1493.

choices.text: It appears most commonly in the third to fifth decades
Infection with high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) is the primary cause
Cystic, slow growing, and locally invasive tumor with a typically indolent course

questions.text: A lesion present in the jaw shows the histologic features which is shown in following microphotograph, which of the following choice is incorrect?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is Ameloblastoma.

  • AMELOBLASTOMA The most common of the epithelial odontogenic tumors.
  • It arises from odontogenic epithelium and does not display ectomesenchymal differentiation.
  • It is cystic, slow growing, and locally invasive with a typically indolent course. (Choice D)
  • Treatment requires wide surgical resection to prevent recurrence.
  • Ameloblastoma exhibiting the classic "follicular" appearance with central stellate reticulum and peripheral palisaded columnar cells with so-called reverse polarization. (Microphotograph)
  • It may arise from the epithelial lining of a dentigerous cyst, from the remnants of the dental lamina and enamel organ, or from the basal layer of the oral mucosa, sometimes in a multicentric fashion.
  • Ameloblastoma appears most commonly in the third to fifth decades. (Choice A).
  • More than 80% occur in the mandible, (Choice B) with 70% of these arising in the molar-ramus area.
  • Infection with high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) is the primary cause of squamous cell carcinoma (Choice C)

Reference: Rosai And Ackerman's Surgical Pathology, 11th Edition, Chapter 5, page number:224.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man with small bowel cancer is treated with chemotherapy. 3 months later, he develops increasing cough and respiratory distress. A chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates. Sputum cultures are negative, and the patient does not respond to antibiotic therapy. A lung biopsy reveals acute and chronic interstitial pneumonitis. There are enlarged cells with prominent, nuclear inclusions (shown in the image). Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient's pulmonary condition?
questions.solution:
In immunocompromised host, infections commonly involve the lung can be classified according to the etiologic agent:

  1. Bacteria
    • P. Aeruginosa
    • Mycobacterium species
    • L. Pneumophila
    • Listeria monocytogenes
  2. Viruses
    • Cytomegalovirus [CMV]
    • herpesvirus
  3. Fungi
    • P. Jiroveci
    • Candida species
    • Aspergillus species
    • Phycomycetes
    • Cryptococcus neoformans

Infected cells are strikingly enlarged, often to a diameter of 40 µm, and show cellular and nuclear pleomorphism. Prominent intranuclear basophilic inclusions spanning one-half of the nuclear diameter are usually set off from the nuclear membrane by a clear halo. (As shown in the image).

Serious, even life-threatening, disseminated CMV infections in immunosuppressed people primarily affect the lungs (pneumonitis) and gastrointestinal tract (colitis). With pulmonary infection, an interstitial mononuclear infiltrate with foci of necrosis develops, accompanied by the typical enlarged cells with inclusions. The pneumonitis can progress to full-blown acute respiratory distress syndrome.

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 8,15, page number:357, 714.

questions.text: Identify the egg shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Given eggs are Barrel shaped, typical shape of Egg of Trichuris Trichiura. Size is around 50-55 micron by 20-25 micron.

They have thick shell and possess a pair of polar plugs at each end. The eggs are unembryonated when passed in stool.

They are brown in colour.

Reference: Ananthnarayan and paniker's textbook of Microbiology 12th edition, page number: 98.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, headache, nuchal rigidity. CSF exam shows gram negative diplococci. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Given case is of Neisseria meningitides, It is gram negative diplococci. Some are intracellular and some are extracellular.

Meningococci are capsulated. They are arranged in half moon shaped.

Trasport medium - Stuarts medium

Blood agar, chocolate agar and muller Hilton agar are use for culture of this bacteria

Modified Thayer martin is also selective media.

It spreads from nasopharynx of person. Carrier stage can also occur.

Clinical feature are fever, headache and nuchal rigidity.

Vaccine is available against it.

Reference: Ananthnarayan and paniker's textbook of Microbiology 12th edition, page number:227

questions.text: An HIV positive patient presents with diarrhoea. Stool AFB stain revealed 4-6 microns structures as shown in the image. What is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
HIV is immunocompromised condition, many opportunistic infection occur in it.

Diarrhoea is one of symptoms due to opportunistic infection.

Cryptosporidium parvum causes diarrhoea in immuno compromised condition

Infective form - oocyst (Contain four sporozoite)

Oocyst is 2to 5 micron in size.

Principle site of infection - small intestine

In patient with AIDS involvement of billiary tract can cause papillary stenosis, sclerosing cholangitis or cholecystitis.

Treatment - currently no effective therapy is available.

Parmomycin - Partially effective in HIV patient.

Nitazoxanide - in children

Reference: Rajesh karyakatte, Text book of parasitology 6th Edition - Page number: 91,92

questions.text: Identify this organism causing diarrhoea?
questions.solution:
Giardia is common cause of diarrhoea.

Giardia is flagellate protozoa, It is common protozoa that inhabits the duodenum and juejunum ( upper small intestine) of human, Infective form -cyst

Mode of transmission - Ingestion of cyst Infective dose is low ingestion of as few as 10 cyst is sufficient to cause infection in human.

Clinical feature varies from asymptomatic carrier to fulminant diarrhea and malabsorption.

Trophozoite adhere to epithelium. They don't cause invasive or locally destructive alteration.

In image trophozoite is shown, it is tennis racket shape, bilateral, symmetrical and all organs of body are paired.

It has sucking disc, two nuclei, four pairs of flagella, axostyle.

Reference: Parasitology by chatterjee 12th edition, page number:39

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with fever, bull's neck appearance as shown in the image. Identify the disease.
questions.solution:
Diphtheria is childhood disease caused by C diphtheria. diphtheria is gram positive, non motile, non sporing, non capsulated

It is stained by albert stain (Special stain), it has meta chromatic granules. Organism are arranged in Chinese letter pattern.

It has many types, Faucial is most common. Larygeal, nasal, cutaneous are other types.

Patient present with bull neck (Swellling of neck). It occurs in faucial.

Patient present with lethargy.

Culture can be done on loeffler serum slope, Tellurite blood agar

Reference: Ananthnarayan and paniker's textbook of Microbiology 12th edition, page number:237

questions.text: Identify the organism
questions.solution:
This image is of HIV. Because it has 2 RNAs, other GP120, GP41, are present only in HIV.

HIV belongs to family of human retroviruses.

HIV is also know as Human T cell Lymphotropic virus.

Lymphadenopathy associated virus.

Nucleocapsid has outer icosahedral shell and inner cone shaped core enclosing the Ribonuceloprotein.

Genome is diploid. Reverse transcriptase enzyme is there.

Reference: Ananthnarayan and paniker's textbook of Microbiology 12th edition, page number:571

questions.text: Identify the disease in given picture?
questions.solution:
It is also know as fifth disease. It is caused by Parvo virus B 19. It spread by respiratory droplets ( Cough and sneeze). By touching contaminated surface. By saliva ( Kissing or shared drinks). By skin to skin, By mother to baby.

Clinically face rash looks as if the cheeks were slapped. Sore throat , slight fever, upset stomach, headache, fatique and itcing

Serological tests are there to rule out this condition. PCR is available to detect parvo virus B 19 viremia.

Reference: Ananthnarayan and paniker's textbook of Microbiology 12th Edition, page number 450.

questions.text: Identify the organism
questions.solution:
Given image is of MicroGametocyte of P falciparum. Because gametocyte of P Falciparum is banana shaped Or sausage shaped with pale blue or pink cytoplasm, large diffuse nucleus

Macrogamete are - crescentic deep blue cytoplasm, compact nucleus.

While p Vivax Microgamate are Spherical, compact pale blue cytoplasm diffuse nucleus

Macrogamate large spherical deep blue cytoplasm

Reference: Chatterjee, textbook of parasitology 12th edition, page number:79

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy comes into the emergency room with the symptoms of abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bloody diarrhoea and drowsiness. Upon asking, he tells the doctor that he has ingested some attractive looking seeds and the seeds that are found in his pocket look like the image given below. What are these seeds that caused him the given symptoms?
questions.solution:
Abrus Precatorius (Rati, Gunchi, Jequirity)

  • Distribution: It is found all over India, and belongs to Leguminosae family. All parts of the plant are poisonous.
  • Signs and Symptoms
    • On ingestion, there is abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bloody diarrhoea, weakness, cold perspiration, trembling of hands, weak pulse, rectal bleeding, tachycardia, headache, dilated pupils, hallucinations drowsiness, tetany and circulatory collapse, seen in 6 h but may be delayed to 1-3 days.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology Third Edition Page Number:519

questions.text: What does the following image suggest while performing the postmortem of a victim?
questions.solution:
Cadaveric spasm

  • A condition in which the muscles of the body which were in a state of contraction immediately before death, continue to be so after death without passing through the stage of primary relaxation
  • Cadaveric spasm, being an antemortem phenomenon, reflects the last act of the subject performed before and at the time of his death. The cause and the manner of death may be judged.
  • In case of drowning, the hand may firmly grip sand, mud, gravel or weed which are present in the pond or lake from where the body was recovered (As given in the image).

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology Third Edition Page Number:144,145

questions.text: What is the technique of opening the calvarium in fetus and neonate shown in the given image called?
questions.solution:
In fetuses and infants, Beneke's technique is used to open the skull. The cranium and dura on both the sides are cut with blunt scissors starting at the lateral edge of the anterior fontanelle extending the incisions along the midline and the lateral sides of the skull. The midline strip about 1 cm wide containing the superior sagittal sinus and the falx is left, and also an intact area in the temporal squama on either side, which serves as a hinge when the bone is reflected in a 'butterfly' manner.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology Third Edition Page Number:321
